title: Regulation in American History
yc_attrs: This course can be applied towards the Humanities and Arts Yale College distributional requirement.
description: Regulation can correct market failures and protect vulnerable groups from exploitation, but it also can impose needless costs while allowing select groups to enrich themselves at societyâ€™s expense. In this seminar, we examine how regulatory policies are created, sustained, and eliminated by examining cases drawn from the scope of American history. Each class explores efforts by political, civic, and business entrepreneurs to solve a specific problem through regulation or, in some cases, deregulation. We investigate how these entrepreneurs have vied to implement their strategies by exploiting or reconciling conflicts between local, state, federal, and supranational approaches to formal or informal regulatory governance. We also emphasize how these agents of change addressed the tensions inherent in balancing an adherence to international commitments with the pursuit of domestic political, social, and economic objectives. By examining how these entrepreneurs have navigated this constellation of regulation and have assembled coalitions in order to put their chosen approaches into practice, we gain a comprehensive perspective on the ability and limitations of different layers of government to reshape individual business sectors, international relations, and democratic institutions.
